review_title: The leader makes or breaks job satisfaction
pros: I have held positions across the company for 13 years, and I found the pay to be fair, overall. In my experience, job satisfaction depends a lot on your leader, and the leaders above them. I was blessed to leave when I had a wonderful leader. I got really nice performance bonuses the last few years, which I appreciated. The benefits were excellent. Anyway, I left on a good note but have to consider some of my past leaders - so I gave 4 stars.
cons: There were roles where the leader was a micromanager and caused a lot of stress in the workplace. On a different note, the cost (and high deductible) of health insurance was higher than I thought was reasonable.

review_title: Good luck getting a boss who knows how to do your work.
pros: Benefits and pay are nice
cons: Don't ask too many questions to leadership, they do not like their decisions being questioned or challenged, even if for more clarification. Leadership has scheduled vacations the exact same tome huge projects are rolled out leaving nobody with a resource for assistance or help. General Customer Service is terrible. When their call volume gets too high leadership tell us to cold transfer any calls out of scope for CSR department. This creates a massive influx of misrouted calls to other departments company wide. When CSR Department is backed up, all of Humana feels the impact of it since they won't higher more people or make sure that CSR is transferring the call appropriately. This workplace is severely political, if someone in leadership does not like you, you don't have a chance here, it is like an elite club. Humana also has a terrible job of hiring completely unqualified people for leadership roles. Not a single boss I have had in 13 years (but 1) has had either a related degree or experience in the actual work that we do... Humana does not hire leaders, they hire managers.

pros: There are ample opportunities to grow and learn at Humana. I had my main official position in QA, but there were multiple opportunities provided for me. I was temporary team lead, project manager, consultant, reporting, programming, trainer, enrollment guide, and the list goes on and on! Loved the opportunities to grow and learn, to be able to enhance our work environment with the tasks we revamped and created!
cons: With all the opportunities provided, I was still at an entry level position and when the time came for the annual incentive bonus or my raise, it was humiliating. By the time the deductions for their part was taken, it was less than my bi-weekly payroll check. I kept a total of how much money the company was making from my contributions and savings, and they could easily have compensated me fairly for my loyalty, time, and contributions to the company.

review_title: Old-school company that’s ripe for change
job_title: Market Development Principal in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Ability to work remotely, with reliable technology and tech support
Competitive salary and benefits 
Truly world class leaders heading diversity, inclusion and health equity initiatives 
Requires most employees to have COVID vaccinations, which is appropriate for a healthcare company
Recent re-orgs will position Humana to be a more relevant and competitive company
cons:
Humana is unique among large health insurance companies by having a disproportionate share of associates remain in the same department of the same company for 15, 20, or 25+ years.  The continued use of outdated processes creates significant barriers to innovation, and associates’  narrow expertise and lack of external experience severely impacts the company’s ability to make decisions, as evidenced by the disastrously non-competitive 2022 Medicare benefits offerings that resulted in loss of enrollment. Because of those membership losses, the company has had to eliminate a  large number of jobs, freeze hiring, and restructure much of the organization. The restructure is long overdue, but unfortunately the layoffs have resulted in the loss of new talent as well as long term employees.

Although Humana has stellar executive leadership heading  diversity, inclusion, and health equity initiatives, not all executive management has embraced diversity. Additionally, many of the old-school Humana leaders do not understand modern management principles and are lacking the skills necessary to lead their teams.

review_title: Horrible Health Insurance Coverage / Management Doesn't Care
pros: The pay is fair and I'm able to work remotely.
cons: I have been with Humana for 10 years. The Humana Health/Dental/Vision Insurance coverage is horrible. There are very few providers in my area who accept it. Everywhere me and my family go we have to self-pay (which includes a recent surgical procedure and 3 days in the hospital). This is forcing me out of a role that I have worked hard for. I've brought this up to management over the years, and it quickly gets dismissed.

pros: Humana has a great core philosophy of putting people first. This means a concentration on what healthcare is best for the member at the right time, in the right manner. Despite all of the hurdles of the US Healthcare system, in many ways Humana transcended the usual business to make members fell cared for and to ensure that they has access to the resources that would lead to their best health.
cons: As with many companies that grow quickly, Humana suffered from the proliferation of too many internal departments and vendor and consultancy relationships. This resulted in the duplication of roles and functions. Sadly for me, the termination of my role was part of what was likely a much-needed reduction in force to remove a lot of duplication and waste.

review_title: Awful company, will fire you for no reason, I have a family to support.
job_title: Grievances and Appeals Representative in Atlanta, GA
pros: Literally nothing positive about working with this crap company.
cons: Micromanaging, awful management, awful trainers, awful people. They called me into a meeting 5 minutes into my shift and fired me saying the workload is too low. I’m PREGNANT! I have a family to support! The workload is NOT TO LOW!!! I will be getting a lawyer! AWFUL PLACE!!!!!

pros: I work with the absolute best people and have for as long as I have been at Humana. They truly go out of their way to hire the nicest people on the planet. They are very open culturally, with diverse hiring practices. They fully accept LGBTQ+, minorities, vets, you name it. Extremely progressive. Most of my leaders have been women and/or people of color. They also hit work/life balance out of the park. Very flexible work options such as working from home or flex scheduling were offered *years* before it became the norm during the pandemic. Paid time off is still good but has gone downhill over the last few years. We moved from a split pool (PTO and Sick Time) to a combined pool with overall fewer hours. At my current tenure, I get over a day off every 2 week pay period
cons: Pay is just so-so. They aim for 75th percentile. Over the years my pay increases have only averaged about 3% a year, at close to 2 decades of service. My big bumps have come from changing roles within the company. And that is for someone who consistently has outstanding performance reviews. Medical benefits are also kinda so-so - as someone who has seen what other companies offer their employees, Humana leaves much to be desired. It's not bad, but it's not great. Retirement funding isn't bad, but our 401k administrator is NOT A FIDUCIARY. If you don't know why that is important, you need to catch up quickly. Paid time off is still good but has gone downhill over the last few years. We moved from a split pool (PTO and Sick Time) to a combined pool with overall fewer hours. At my current tenure, I get over a day off every 2 week pay period.

job_title: Grievance and Appeals Coordinator in Lexington, KY
pros: None. It’s a terrible place for employment
cons: Retaliatory treatment received on an ongoing basis while employed at Humana. I received a final warning and steps to terminate me without a first warning and reasons that were unwarranted. I am a dedicated, hardworking employee who cares about our members. I truly believe I was given a the warning because I tried to bring attention to the massive flaws in our work flow, in our department, and in the management here at Humana. I spent over a year away from my family while sending ignored messages to all levels of management. I believe I provided great ideas and insight on how to make the expedite process better for not only our members but for our employees. I provided pages and pages of examples of things said and done to me and others on my team with no response. I watched people leave while leadership used the excuse they couldn’t handle expedite, when in reality these were amazing associates who just couldn’t stand being treated poorly anymore. I personally recivef a final warning for saying “BS” (not the actual words, just those letters). I can assure you I have heard so much worse in our TEAM chat, by our leadership, and by the members who expect and deserve the best service they count on and pay for. Our team chat was so toxic it was deleted and taken from us so we could not communicate with each other or support one another. Members on our team as well as myself were continually punished for questioning the lack of leadership and direction and in the end it is costing you an employee who not only worked hard, stayed late, produced great work and actually CARED about the member. While working case work of others I have discovered there are so many employees that are poorly trained and whose cases are literally a train wreck. Records are not being requested appropriately, AOR’s are being requested with no return phone number to call back to inform them what is missing or the steps that need to be taken to get their loved ones the help they so desperately need. Autofowards are at an all time high yet leadership has time to threaten and intimidate the very people who voice their opinions (like me) who are genuinely trying to make this a better working environment so that we can provide quality services to our members. I hope the leadership reviews the many emails I have sent pertaining to the toxic work environment and how poorly the employees in this department are treated, no one should be expect to work 10 hr days 6-7 days a week. The lack of accountability that is enforced is is puzzling to me, there seems to be no structure and leadership is nonexistent after 5:30. I truly believe you will continue to lose solid employees when you are asking people to “check in” on Saturdays when they are scheduled off. No one will stay at a company who treats people as poorly as they do their own members when they can walk in to a new salaried position, making over $60,000 with no weekends and no holidays with other companies as I left this week for one of those opportunities.

review_title: Work from home but stressful expectations and sub-industry pay
pros:
Eligible for some benefits as a Variable Staff Pharmacist
Supervisors and many coworkers were nice enough
Okay job for those who desperately need a job without other immediate options
Got to work from home
cons:
Pay is one of the lowest I have encountered as a pharmacist and appears to get lower every year.
 Case rate expectations are high with quality goals that are very hard to hit. Seems like most people get weeded out and let go through the 1st few months after training.
Every second is measured through clock punches which is converted to metrics.
 Not enough time to properly review the case along with the numerous computer systems and internal/external resources you are expected to use for reviews
 Will cut your shift or rearrange your schedule via unpaid "split-shifting" method that requires you to still stick around to work later but have to wait unpaid until you can.
 Seems like they change their minds on how to do things or make things more difficult on an almost weekly basis making it very difficult to not make mistakes. 
Actual direction help getting your questions answered can sometimes be difficult. 
Small chance or long wait times for getting full time status. From speaking with others seems like at least a 2 year waiting period to get a FTE position even if you consistently meet expectations.

I've been working as a lead for a long time in several respected companies and I felt ashamed to report for such a terrible, untalented and unhinged person.

review_title: If you like being micromanaged, DMS Sales Agent is the job for you!
job_title: Dms Sales Agent in Miramar, FL
pros: The benefits are relatively good, but not great when compared to even Marketplace plans. People outside of DMS Sales seem to like the company.
cons: The micromanaging! It’s a work-from-home call center environment and they have something called “Aux Time” or as some of the managers call it “AUX Hawk!!” Aux is when you have been off the phone and not taking incoming calls. Now, I am not an employee who is EVER late from breaks and I am ALWAYS on time (mostly sitting at my computer early most days!) and the managers often EMAIL to all  a list of people who are off the phones, even if it’s their lunch break! Micromanaging at its worst! If you make one mistake, you’ll get written up. In the past year, we have had 4 different managers because the atmosphere is HORRIBLE! Had I known it was going to be like this, I would’ve kept my previous job! But I took the job because outwardly, in the communities we serve, Humana “seems” like a great company! They want WE employees to treat Humana Members well - but how can we do that when The Man’s foot is on our neck- waiting for us to make a mistake? If you’re thinking of coming here to work for DMS, DON’T! The DMS management is straight up Trash!

review_title: Eyes wide open, don't be surprised
pros: They give you a wealth of training, mentoring, and take people into the industry without Medicare experience if they have the sales skills needed. The job has a decent base pay and allows you to earn commission and added a very small residual monthly payment the last year I was here.
cons: We had a once a year picnic as a center to have a social time with the team. Considering there was never any outings, events, or gatherings as time went on they turned it into a amazon mass production environment, hired car salesman for managers and associate directors. They would measure everything you did, or didn't do and would immediately plot how they could fire you. They would preach how we're all family, and empathy, understanding, and caring but is all smoke. Covid happened and then eliminated all team functions (which was one by this point), made everyone work from home immediately. The organization wasn't ready for the change, didn't offer internet reimbursement or anything. Then they began threatening everyone in the organization if hundreds of people to get the covid shots or risk being fired. That went on right before AEP and lasted for almost 6 months till after OEP. Religious exemption would not be accepted unless it was a legal document from a religious group, pastor, or doctor that would sign off (which are also being controlled by the insurance companies). There came a point I had enough, and if they are going to gas line their talent of all levels, I began to reflect whether this company is even in line with what I believe and not consistent with what they preach. Very very very money hungry organization that has no morals, ethics, and everyone is just out for themselves. Bunch of car sales wanting to run a organization like its a sales job, vs a advisor. By the end we didn't see our teammates, manager, center, Customer and NO ONE. Yet they hardliners us to get the Vax shots to the bitter end till the Supreme Court declared it unconstitutional. Soulless people trying to help people...just business as usual

pros: I have been extremely fortunate to have been placed on two teams that are outstanding and supportive. I have also been blessed with two outstanding Coaches and Clinical Operations Managers. I work from home, I can look ugly if I want, the worst part of the commute is a cat in the hallway. When I turn off the computer at the end of the day, work is done and that is wonderful for me.   PTO is generous, my coach is flexible in working with me with school, elderly family members and my own health as long as productivity is met. Work/life balance is encouraged. Lots of health and wellness incentives.
cons:
I don't have many cons. But, the worst would be this: about 6 months after I started there was a distinct culture shift from quality to quantity. Upper management can deny it all they want, but that's what it is. Every position on my side of the telephonic business is having their feet held to the fire to meet incredibly high member "connects" every day, week and month. Not only that, there are elements withing those calls that are being measured as well like talk time for the day and referrals to other departments. So, if my talk time is way up and my number of contacts is down, I may have spent too much time on the phone with the members. Or if I reached a high number of members and my talk time was low my quality may come into question and my calls may be scrutinized. So, saying this you are probably thinking that I am working in customer service and need to stop whining, right?? NO! I work with members regarding their health needs, encouraging health goals, answering questions and providing resources if needed. Yeah. The goal for my day would certainly be attainable IF every person I called answered the phone.  I have a coworker that made 45 calls to get only 11 successful connects for the day. They all have to be documented too btw. This doesn't include any anomalies in charts that need to be addressed and passed up the chain either. 
I can go on but I won't.  Bottom line is quality will fall if quantity continues to be the push. All things cycle. I hope this kidney stone passes soon because it hurts like hades!

job_title: Senior Learning Design Professional in Louisville, KY
pros:
Humana is a great company to work for with many perks. I don't feel micromanaged or pressured to take every single assignment. The salary is middle of the road good, and the benefits are excellent compared to most places I have worked. About half the staff were working from home before the pandemic, so very employee centered. Many of the employees have been working here for years (if not decades), so apparently Humana keeps doing something right to retain them.

Medical is standard HDHP or Copay with a noticeably lower monthly cost than most places (its their own insurance of course). HSA is offered for the HDHP, but not much matching there compared to other companies (lower premiums probably make up the difference). Dental and Vision are pretty standard across the board. They have an excellent 401k match of 125% up to 6% of your annual salary contributions. I've never seen a company go over 100%. Although you have to stay 2 years to get their match vested in your Charles Schwab account.

Each year you get a bonus up to a certain percentage of your salary based on company performance. You are told this max percentage when you are offered the position. First year you are prorated, but then you get the full amount after that. My first bonus was nearly the top amount, so Humana is not short changing you there. Time off is pretty standard with PTO time (sick and vacation combined). You earn almost a day per pay period, but no increase until year 9. Flexibility though is offered by most supervisors for appointments, so you don't get nickel and dimed for every doctor, dentist, or pickup the kid from school time off. Generous bereavement leave of 5 days off per event.
cons:
There are not many, but a few nitpicks here and there. Salary increases are annual and determined based on work through December (although November this past year). Problem is that if you worked there less than 6 months during the evaluation period, then no annual increase for you. They used to give raises that following March, but now it is July. I was just short my first year of hitting 6 months (as of this past November cutoff) and so I really won't get one until technically 2 years after starting here.

Another issue I had was that their computer software is really locked down. Like software you have approved and installed on your computer will not take updates unless you get the admin password. This is fine for some products, but others have constant updates and are locked out from updating (and bug you constantly to update). You have to get IT to update the program for you if it is approved. And many times the software upgrade doesn't work (because it is locked down), so you then have to spend extra time get things fixed.

This year they have this "Save a $1 Billion Dollars" campaign company wide. Sounds scarier than it was at the time (as that seems like layoff speak). This is because they had less enrollments than expected. Not that they lost enrollments mind you. So, just remember that this is a FOR profit health insurance company.

job_title: Dms Sales Agent in San Antonio, TX
pros: Commission + Overtime pay is nice. When and IF you make inbound it is non-stop calls with the opportunity to really cash out. Literally calls are non-stop all day. Be ready! (15 minute break twice a day, and a 30 minute lunch) Be ready!
cons:
At the end of the day this is just another sales job. Telemarketing in a very competitive/over-saturated industry. Some people claim they love the culture, but honestly working here is like being in a cult. A Big lime-green Humana cult. Agents are so tethered to their phones trying to make another dollar that most forget or simply abandon a life outside of work. It’s very evident as most agents and managers are all dating each other and rarely venture out of the Humana bubble that consumes them. Sales managers are pretentious and numb, and almost all of them come as failures from their previous careers and endeavors that they end up selling insurance for way longer than they should. Most managers encourage immoral (not illegal) sales practices (not all, but most of ‘em) and yes, that’s the nature of sales, but Medicare is not a product that should be ‘sold’ to begin with.  It feels wrong changing older peoples plans and “selling” different plans to existing customers for the sake of call conversion. There are real people on the other end of the line whose lives are being torn apart just so we can meet our sales goals. 

Also, Dental insurance literally does not help most folks save. It’s really just a hindrance for people getting the work they really need done. Seriously look up dental insurance, it’s really sad.

review_title: Humana is like any other health insurance company despite the positive marketing .
pros: You can work in a value-based Medicare Advantage space.
cons: Humana sounds like a great place to work when reading the website descriptions and marketing information. But once inside, it is like any other large corporation. CEO, Bruce Broussard, sends out a weekly e-mail to all employees which reads very well and for a moment you feel inspired to reach for the Bold Goal. However, the reality does not match the dream. Like any other company, your work experience is largely dictated by the supervisor before you and their behavior: toxic, microagressive, micromanaging, critical, etc. Humana does not sufficiently vet who is chosen for management roles to determine if they possess the qualities of a servant leader. Instead, people are plugged into roles who obviously satisfied a technical or emotional need of upper management without regard for who best to lead staff in their needs of growth and development, i.e. a seemingly high IQ is chosen without a matching EQ. Notice the use of the word management, in my time here I have not met a true leader but they like to call themselves “leadership.” Think twice about Humana before looking for a greener pasture.

pros: Paycheck and that is all.
cons:
This job is soul-sucking. There is no work life balance, good luck getting a PTO day especially on Fridays or Mondays.
You have to fight for it like a pack of wolves with others in same department. (even in the off season with lower call volume) Get used to your schedule changing during shift bids without management even looking at your request. 

Every day, every call you get a part of you dies. You see it in the strict policies in place by the Center of Medicaid/Medicare Services and having to relay said policies to the beneficiaries that keep them trapped in a health plan that is life threatening if unable to disenroll and go back to original Medicare. So many rules.

If you have a MA plan you can't get out but if you have MAPD then you can, and so many bogus others that make the older population feel trapped and that's what they will tell you daily- how trapped they feel and why they can't change it. 
And let's not get started on the "licensed sales agents" more like crooks that will bend a hand to get their commission. 

This job is eye opening to how busted the system is and you will be the one to relay that daily. God speed.

pros: Benefits and Work From Home
cons: Daily IT issues, phone call volume, Points per call metrics, horrible training. If you are a seasoned agent, BEWARE and STAY CLEAR!!! Your phone issues will start day 1 of AEP and the entire system will go down. New agents are brought on to ONLY make OUTBOUND calls to current members who have been pounded all year long already with an abundance of calls while the very selective veterans take all the INBOUND calls. You will find your questions and concerns falling on deaf ears. Don't expect your manager to assist with jumping on calls if needed, expect to enter countless IT tickets daily, and right when you think this can work by reaching your goal gets you Inbound; think again. This place has a metric that grades you on points per call no matter what. Meaning, customer can be calling in to request a new card or complain and if you don't sell them a policy, that counts towards your metrics. You can exceed the AEP or OEP goal by 20 applications and still be placed on Outbound campaign because of your points per call. Expect your training class to be extremely large with only 3 trainers. The blind will be leading the blind and you will soon learn, none of that training works when you get on the phones. Expect to learn nothing from the TOP PERFORMING agents. You will not be able to listen to their calls, instead, you will more likely be listening to your colleagues calls from your training class.

pros: Not many Pros. Possible career growth (but barely), maybe the health benefits? Also, its work from home.
cons:
Everything. First and foremost, I was an Inbound Contacts Representative 1 for Humana's HCPR Department for a year and 7 months. When I initially started out, I was told I'd see career growth amongst other amazing and inclusive things, which is why I accepted the job. This was always promised, but it was never given. It was a call center job, but I thought I’d move up pretty quickly considering I have a college degree and good experience. I wanted a foot in the door. The year and 7 months I was there was the most miserable I've ever been at any job I’ve ever had, and I’ve worked retail for longer. The members will scream at you and curse you out, and your supervisor basically will tell you that you have to suck it up and take it. I was mentally, emotionally, and verbally abused every single day of my life. I left many shifts crying. Yeah, I could've quit earlier, but I had a job secured and that’s what mattered most to me. I had coworkers who were also in the same position as I was, where they were miserable and had no type of life but needed a job and benefits. 
For the department of HCPR, there is a peak period, which will be the worst period of your life. It runs from January to March, and you're not allowed to take days off (PTO) at this time, AND it is MANDATORY to work overtime every single week. I worked at least 10 hours a day, 5-6 days from January to March, and did not have a life outside of work. During peak (and even outside of peak months) calls will be back-to-back. You won't have a single break in between calls, and if a member is angry, you're 100% going to get screamed at by them. During peak, be sure not to make plans, don't make life events, don't get sick. You will have last minute mandatory overtime and be forced to work regardless of what’s going on in your personal life. My team lead would “jokingly” tell my teammates, “Stop getting sick” or “I didn’t approve of you getting sick”. She wasn’t joking. She was being very serious, but hiding it as if it were a joke, because she’d genuinely get upset if people were sick. I had 2 emergency doctor's visits during peak, and I got occurrences for these emergencies. An occurrence is basically an absence, and if you have 3 or more it can result in termination. Now, please tell me why a healthcare company will not excuse you if you have emergency doctors’ visits? They penalize you, even if you have a doctor's note. The doctor’s note means nothing. You're basically treated like a slave. Once you accept that job offer, you are theirs and there isn't anything you can do unless you quit. Even outside of peak months, it is difficult to get a day off. If one person in the department is off on a day, then no one else can have off unless you beg your supervisor. 
Additionally, you will be micromanaged. The micromanaging is real. Never have I ever been so closely watched at work. I was the best on my team (as told by my supervisor) but was still super micromanaged. If you come back from your lunch even 1 minute late, you get questioned and they will remove that time from your pay. You could be bleeding from your eyes and they will still tell you that you have to log into work. I've had teammates who have been sick/had emergencies and were forced to work. 
Emergencies happen, sicknesses happen. Life happens. It's unavoidable. The way employees get in trouble for these life emergencies/happenings is absolutely atrocious. No human should ever have to worry about getting in trouble from their job for having an emergency/life event of any kind. People have things to do after their time at work, and it's not like we can schedule emergencies. Humana, as a healthcare company who highly promotes "well-being" should have a better method to allowing their employees to go to the doctor or if an emergency occurs. It is unfair, unethical, and unhealthy. And lastly, it feels like slave labor. I cannot believe I experienced this first hand, and to have to work through personal emergencies is insane. On top of this, you're getting screamed at. You’re being treated poorly, and it’s not even worth the pay because you’re being deeply underpaid. It’s toxic and I did not feel a single trace of appreciation from my leaders. They have a high turnover rate for this position for a reason. Within a month, my team lost about 6 people. Do yourself a favor and look elsewhere for a job. I do see other great reviews for Humana, so maybe it was just my position. But I wish I can give 0 stars.

review_title: It used to be my dream.
pros: I came to Humana through M&A. I was doing what I loved. I was with people I loved. The company had a purpose, and during this volatile time, I was a big part of the solution. I was trusted and every level of the company could and would ring the phone. It is a big company. The doors were always open.
cons: There was a bad hire who became my leader. I couldn't get help from HR. It turned ugly and my dream ended abruptly. If they want you out, they will set you up to get you out. I've seen it done to others and this time - it was me. I went from an employee of great value to loser in 3 months. That leader was also gone less than a month after I was. This may be VERY isolated, but it is not the only case. There are more great, not good, but great leaders with Humana. It is the bad side that can be devastating. Beware.

pros: Some of the mid level staff are amazing people. There isn't a lot to really say about this job that is good.
cons:
Think about the worst management you ever had and multiply that 10x. Then add in the way they MICRO MANAGE YOU TO DEATH no matter how good you do. 

There is never a kind word, there is never a "Thanks for what you do", its simply management saying "You never do good enough". I feel bad for anyone coming into CenterWell/Humana. Especially with the new management changes, it will be even more confusing and mentally abusive/toxic. 

The management does nothing but mislead you. When you hire in, they tell you that you will work on a few sites then they dump things that are not related nor trained on into your lap. They have been and are still doing this. Also, why the turnover is so high in our region. Management MICROMANAGES you and treats you like trash. On top of having all of this extra work dumped on you, your manager will call you and harass you about ticket SLA's when they are 1 minute over due. This isn't a joke, this is the reality of this place. 

 Your team that you work with locally are great but god forbid you ask something in a chat designated for support. Not only does your own manager degrade you but staff from other sites talk at you and down to you. Manager DOES NOTHING to resolve. He actually encourages it but making little smiley faces and liking the posts of these toxic people. 

 You could argue that it's me, but it is not. We have new employees and old that are over it. This company as a whole will be lucky if there isn't a mass exodus in their IT department. The supervisor is unprofessional, management is unprofessional and supportive of others that are the same way. The CEO i'm sure is unaware or doesn't care at all. If I can save you from the micromanagement, I will. They will hound you while working on another site to be at another site. They know you can't be at both places at once but they do not care. They also track EVERYTHING you do. Micromanage, micromanage, micromanage, micromanage to the nth degree.

I worked at Humana for a year, they give a great training and try to make things fair with shift bids, they also give plenty of PTO. However, They have you cold call and most the times the callers are tired of getting five to six calls a day. The only time OT is available is during AEP. They do offer a generous base pay, but commissions could be a little better.  For an insurance company their employee insurance is a disgrace, completely garbage. And I couldn’t find anyone around me to take it, I was lucky my husband is in the union and I could still use his. The stress of this job was so bad my hair started falling out!! They say people love being there when you get on the job, but you become a tenured agent after a year of working there and you’re vested after two, simply because you quickly find out that people quit left and right! They say they care about their customers, but they truly are all about money!

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Phoenix, AZ
pros: They hire anyone to work there knowing that by the your retention bonus come up you get the 1on1 conference. When they tell your numbers aren’t good enough.
cons: Too many chiefs no Indians have those that are supposed to do the job they are hired for get away without doing it because they kiss up to the right people. There so much politics it’s more like a kindergarten playground. They only care about the numbers. Even the high hitting producers take the unethical short cuts and don’t care who notices it. They cherry pick assignments for themselves and never are corrected for it. All these things drive up the numbers which Humana is only concerned not accurate and professional work ethics. We’ll it’s big business PHarma what else can you expect. The schedule is horrible and they often require you to work mandatory overtime. The work areas are dirty and disorganized. I mean dirt and soot from all those machines that have going constantly. There is a definite toxic smell in various places in the working areas. Causing headaches and nausea it gets that bad. Training is half assed and your penalty is low reviews what they get around to you. By that time it seems to late to fix the problem. They set you up for failure. The associates with many years on the job give no guidance or help it’s like they enjoy watching the new people struggling. Humana is not a kind place to work. Your team members will leave you off to another project and your left not knowing what’s going on. I seen this happen many times. What they are called out on it nobody has anything to say.

cons: To make a long story short, the workload is unbalanced. Favoritism rules this department. If you are a favorite you will not do work while everyone else is being overworked. They do not treat pregnant women fairly. I had a friend that was told she had to cancel her Dr appt when she was in her third trimester because they were busy. I had another friend that was fired because she missed work due to a close relative passing. They fire their best employees because the supervisors did not like them or the best workers left because they were being over worked while those that had favoritism on their side barely worked and were promoted. There is no work/life balance. The work culture is toxic and messy. They expect you to treat higher ups (techs, trainers, supervisors, etc.) with respect while they can talk to you any way. If you do not mind being over worked and made to do mandatory every day, apply. If you want to stay in the same position for years with no to little pay increase, apply. If you want to be criticized (quality review) with no accurate or positive corrective action, apply.

job_title: Senior Business Systems Analyst (IT) in Louisville, KY
pros: Relatively flexible, in terms of start time, end time, amount of notice for days off, generous vacation and personal days, opportunity to learn new skills, or continue your formal education.
cons: All of the above is true of all of Humana, how easily you can find the time to learn new things, or stretch your responsibilities to become something greater, and the number of chances to grow are all dependant on who you work for. The intent of Humana is to be a great place to work, they try every day to be a better place to work than the day before. But old school hard nosed people who feel they have been passed over or never get that shot they are looking for (possibly while Humana was evolving over the years) can be the biggest obstacle to your success. Old Timers are often disgruntled huge obstacles here and seem to go unchecked. This opinion is not being stated based on just one experience. It is a bit of a potluck you never know what your going to get stuck with cause a little bit of everything is in there and sometimes you can get dealt a bad hand.
